experience_assessment: I have published one or two papers in this area.
review_assessment:_thoroughness_in_paper: I made a quick assessment of this paper.
review_assessment:_checking_correctness_: I assessed the sensibility of the experiments.
title: Official Blind Review #1
review_assessment:_checking_correctness_: I assessed the sensibility of the derivations and theory.
review:
The paper presented a method that combines VAE and uncertainty aware GRU for sequential missing data imputation and outcome prediction.  

Pros:
>modeling heterogeneous sequential data with missing value is an important task, especially in the healthcare domain.  
>The presentation of the method is easy to follow. 
>The experiments compared with many baselines 

Cons:
>Figure 2 should compare the D-GRU (che 2018) cell which is the baseline as well. Comparing to D-GRU, I am not sure what is the contribution as the GRU-D has considered both the delay \Delta and the delay \gamma. Please clarify.
> Also many works have studied  VAE + sequential model. Combining with the previous point. I don't see sufficient novelty in this work apart from using the standard VAE + sequential formula with D-GRU. 
>How does alpha and gamma from equation (11) been chosen? I guess that the performance is sensitive to these parameters. 
>The experiments are weak as it is only evaluated on one dataset (PhysioNet).
>Improvement shows in Table 2 are not significant considering std comparing with other methods. 
>There are many VAE based methods for missing value such as [1][2], and the uncertainty is used for downstream tasks [2]. 
>It would be great to have analysis comparing with non-sequential VAE based imputation method etc and discuss which part of the design contributed most to the performance gain. 

[1] Mattei, Pierre-Alexandre, and Jes Frellsen. "MIWAE: Deep Generative Modelling and Imputation of Incomplete Data Sets."
[2] Ma, Chao, et al. "Eddi: Efficient dynamic discovery of high-value information with partial VAE." arXiv preprint arXiv:1809.11142 (2018).
